Following the Train: A Rough Return to San Andreas

Introduction:
GTA San Andreas Definitive Edition beckons players back to the vibrant streets of Los Santos, San Fierro, and Las Ventruas in a remastered version of the beloved classic. However, while it seeks to reignite the nostalgia of the original game and modernize the experience, it falters in execution, resulting in a journey through San Andreas that is marred by technical issues and missed opportunities. In this review, we'll explore the highs and lows of this remastered edition.

Nostalgic Remaster:
For fans of the original GTA San Andreas, the Definitive Edition offers a chance to revisit the iconic world of San Andreas with a fresh coat of paint. The updated graphics, improved character models, and reimagined environments evoke a sense of nostalgia, transporting players back to the bustling streets and diverse landscapes of Los Santos, San Fierro, and Las Venturas. Rediscovering classic missions, memorable characters, and iconic landmarks is a nostalgic trip down memory lane that fans will appreciate.

Enhanced Controls and Features:
GTA San Andreas Definitive Edition introduces modernized controls and quality-of-life improvements to enhance the gameplay experience. The addition of updated controls, improved camera mechanics, and refined aiming mechanics makes navigating the sprawling cityscape and engaging in combat feel more intuitive and responsive. Quality of life features such as autosave functionality and enhanced checkpoint systems help to streamline the experience, reducing frustration and enhancing accessibility for players.

Technical Issues and Bugs:
Despite its efforts to improve upon the original game, GTA San Andreas Definitive Edition suffers from numerous technical issues and bugs that hinder the overall experience. Players may encounter frequent framerate drops, texture pop-in, and other graphical glitches that disrupt immersion and detract from the visual fidelity of the game. These technical shortcomings can be particularly frustrating and detract from the enjoyment of revisiting San Andreas.

Lack of Substantial Updates:
While the Definitive Edition offers updated visuals and some quality-of-life improvements, it lacks significant updates or additions to the gameplay experience. Beyond the revamped graphics and controls, the core gameplay remains largely unchanged from the original release, offering little in the way of fresh content or innovation. Players hoping for new missions, activities, or gameplay mechanics may be disappointed by the lack of substantial updates, leaving the experience feeling somewhat stagnant.

Conclusion:
GTA San Andreas Definitive Edition offers a bumpy return to Los Santos, blending nostalgia with frustration in its remastered rendition of the classic title. While it successfully recaptures the essence of the original game and provides a nostalgic trip down memory lane, it struggles to overcome technical issues and missed opportunities for meaningful updates. Despite its flaws, it remains a worthwhile experience for fans of the series looking to revisit San Andreas with a fresh perspective, albeit with some bumps along the road.

Oh, where do I even begin with the GTA Definitive Edition? It's like they took our beloved San Andreas, Vice City, and GTA III, put them in a blender, and hit the "definitive" button. But hey, at least Carl Johnson finally learned to fly – and not just in the metaphorical sense!

I fired up the game, ready for some nostalgia, only to witness Carl take flight during a high-speed chase. I mean, talk about character development! Move over, CJ, there's a new pilot in town. Who needs a pilot's license when you have the power of the definitive edition, right?

The graphics? Well, let's just say they are so definitive that even my toaster would be unimpressed. I half-expected Carl's lowrider to break into a dance routine at any moment, just to distract me from the pixelated mess around.

The pedestrians on the streets seem to have taken their dance lessons from the lowriders. They twist and turn in ways that would make a contortionist jealous. It's like the whole city is participating in a synchronized dance-off, and Carl is the unwitting judge.

Remember the iconic Grove Street gang? Yeah, they've upgraded from gang signs to interpretative dance. Now, when I roll up in my stolen car, they break into a routine that could rival Broadway. Who knew gang life was so rhythmically diverse?

But let's not forget the best part – the flying cars. I don't know if it's a feature or a bug, but watching cars soar through the skies like they've got wings is pure entertainment. Liberty City Airlines, move over; Carl Airlines has just been established, and it's taking off – literally.

All in all, the GTA Definitive Edition is a wild ride. It's a trip down memory lane, complete with glitches, dance-offs, and Carl Johnson defying the laws of gravity. If you can overlook the graphical hiccups and embrace the chaos, you might just find yourself laughing your way through the streets of Los Santos. Carl, my man, you may not have fixed the family, but at least you've learned to spread your wings and fly – quite literally!

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

For anyone wondering “if the Definitive Edition worth it?”: yes, It does.
I would say. Definitive Edition is so much better than the original.

Yes, I watched numerous Youtube videos criticizing Definitive Edition, they are all correct, if you put DE under a microscope, DE has many flaws. Like extremely low polygon buildings in the far distance, CJ's first girlfriend has a cartoonish face, blurred graffiti on the wall, they are all there, they are all true. But are you really bothered by it?  I wasn’t. 

But the DE has many improvement that’s game changing.

1.Better graphics. It’s far better looking than that old PS2 game.
No more 30 FPS frame lock! Original GTA:SA has 30FPS frame lock, and it ties to the physical engine, you can’t increase it by mod. I am playing 120 FPS in the DE version, it’s smooth. 

2.GPS routing! Such a basic function didn’t exist until GTA4. now the DE version has it. 

3.Checkpoint and auto-save! Original game doesn’t have it, so if you failed a mission, ready spending minutes run back and re-accept your mission. DE just save your time.

4.Borderless Windowed! Another basic function people take for granted but didn’t exist before.

5.Low mouse sensitivity and smooth aiming with mouse! I can set my mouse to 1600 DPI or higher with DE version. But I can only use 400 DPI if I play the original game, and the aiming was still awful, mouse acceleration was crazy back then.

6. Better car control. Cars just have easier control overall, and acceleration is faster for all cars.


I had the origin GTA:SA, I hated it so bad, I played it 3 hours, it made my rage quit and removed that game from library. But with DE version, I 100% finished the game and unlocked all achievements.

But to the game itself, GTA:SA is 20 years old game(reviewed at 2023 november), everything about this game screaming “old game” to you. Old game look, old game design, old game control, everything is old. Yes, GTA:SA is a classic in the video game history, but Super Mario at Famicon is a classic too. If you play that today, you won’t like it like you were in 1990.

So don’t expect some absolutely amazing game experience. Whether you like this game or not depends on your tolerance for old games.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition..
Did I expect too much from the word “definitive” edition? Honestly, it falls short of my expectations, but overall, I think it's a good remake version of the original game(Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas, 2005), so I'll give it a positive review.
In order to keep the unique atmosphere of the original game intact, developers have made changes to the appearance of characters and the designs of its map, and improved the user-interface(UI) without making major changes throughout the game. However, this may give customers the perception that the game was made at ease from a different perspective. It is true that this criticism is inevitable due to additional bugs and glitches, and inconveniences that were not found in the original game. From this point of view, I'll briefly write down the pros and cons of this game, and the conclusion.

PROS
-Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is the LEGEND, and it will never be changed. It still excites us until now.
- Improved graphics and weapon aiming compared to the original.
- The UI has been improved, and it certainly seems to be convenient in that field. (weapon selection, stats check, etc.)
- Elaborate the game more carefully and diversify the customization of the protagonist and vehicles (such as new and detailed food menus and car customization)
- Glitches in the specific missions in the original version are mostly removed and the difficulty level has been well-adjusted, making some overly difficult missions easier for beginners. The overall difficulty is well-adjusted. I definitely like that.
- Add Steam achievements

CONS
- Many bugs and glitches that were not in the original are newly created. (For example, a player can pass through obstacles at will, and there is a glitch where the character is moving to a strange place or falling out of the air.)
- Still stupid AI and NPCs reaction
- Uncomfortable with its control. (Plalyers’ sight is continuously forced forward, so it is impossible to look around.)
- It's hard to feel a big difference compared to the original. So it makes me feel like the developers have made the game at ease (it feels like I'm playing a mod made by amateur)
-The price is too expensive considering the quality of this game.

Conclusion
Anyway, it's a good remake version of GTA: SA, and the developers' intentions themselves deserve high praise. Therefore, I'll give it a positive review. If you're new to playing GTA: SA, it's worth buying it for over 50% off. However, if you've played the original GTA: SA, I recommend you to buy it at least 80% off. If you compare it to the original, not the game itself, there will be NO significant difference, or you can find many disadvantages and glitches. Don't expect too much and evaluate the definitive version as it is!

On the positive side, the game remains as fun as ever and even more completion-friendly. The core gameplay, storyline, and open-world sandbox elements that made San Andreas a beloved title are still intact, ensuring hours of entertainment.

This remaster offers a mixed experience. While the updated graphics can be impressive, the changes to character appearances and the introduction of some bugs might detract from the overall experience. It's still a solid 8 in your book, which suggests that despite its flaws, the game retains its inherent charm and appeal.

I got the trilogy and this is the first game from it that I played. GTA SA will always hold a very special place in my heart for its astonishingly amazing story. The problems with this game, though, are the reasons why I don't recommend this remaster to other people. Firstly, the bugs. All of the glitches in this game that make it unplayable are super annoying as well. There are some lighthearted bugs that they fixed like the one where if you go in first person mode on a bicycle and then apply rear view, it just zooms in to CJ's face, which is pretty funny, but they patched that. I had a save file corruption at one point that made the game simply unplayable. When you open up the save file, I'm in freemode near a floppy disk as usual. But when you go outside, there are multiple invisible fighter jets constantly shooting rockets at you no matter where you go. You can be under a bridge and the missiles will explode on the bridge but still damage you. So I had to heroically get in a car, drive to a mission which wasn't that far away, and get there but with the risk of being bombed by invisible fighter jets. I got to the mission and completed it. After that, I didn't get the glitch again, but it sure was something that made me quit the game for a couple weeks. That was the only unplayable glitch that I encountered, but people have reported encountering much more severe glitches than mine. Secondly, the graphics. For a remaster, the graphics are horrible and I had to change a bunch of settings to make the game at least slightly presentable. I would honestly prefer the old PS2 graphics over this garbage. The remaster removed so much of the emotion from the characters' faces. It also deformed their faces. A prime example of this is Officer Tenpenny's face. The old version had emotion and looked like a real face. The remaster, however, looks so much worse and deformed. This remaster of our favorite childhood GTA games could of been so much better. They could've revamped the map to make it look more photo-realistic instead of the cartoony look that it currently has. They even could've remodeled the characters' faces to make them look way better, and they could've animated the characters' movements with motion capture like they did for GTA 5 and took the old sound bytes of their voices and applied accurate lip movements. But instead, Rockstar, like the greedy scoundrels they are, decided to employ a company that makes mobile games for the remaster and pocket all of the change. Truly despicable.

I just spent roughly 40 hours to 100% this game, and I can pretty safely say I don't think I'll play this again. If I ever get the urge to play San Andreas again (Give it a year), I'm just going to play the Classic version.

The 3D models are wild. It feels in their attempt to smooth out the jagged edges of the 2004 models involved opening them up in Maya, and hitting 3 to smooth out the mesh. Which results in the straight up breaking of some of the models. 
The quality of these models is nothing to write about either, with most of the character models looking very similar to an assessment for 3D characters I submitted when I was in animation school, and that is [u]not[/u] boasting on my part, I did not do well in that assessment.

It's genuinely impressive that this 'remaster' managed to break as many things as it did. 
The camera controls in vehicles is an absolute mess, would you like to look up or down? [i]Too bad.[/i] 
Would you like to look anywhere but straight ahead for 2 seconds while? [i]Not happening, buddy.[/i] 
There are even some bizarre choices, like removing the ability to rebind certain keys for aircrafts. So anytime I wanted to change radio station, I would put my landing gear down, or using flares in the hydra, would also fire machine guns. 
That's without me even touching on all of the tears in the map, I genuinely lost count of the amount of times ground textures were not aligned correctly, resulting in a glimpse into the abyss of nothing. Visually, that sucks, but while collecting Oysters, I actually fell through one of these tears, so unfortunately it's not just a visual issue.

On its own, things like these aren't that big of an issue, but when these issues didn't exist in an almost 20 year old version of the game. It's very hard to recommend this game, and it's even harder to call it the [i]definitive[/i] way to play GTA San Andreas.

Just so I wasn't [i]completely[/i] negative about this game, sometimes the lighting looked okay. Like the neon lights of Las Venturas at night. Compared to the previous installment, the story moved several years forward and to the opposite coast of the United States. Welcome to sunny San Andreas.
You step into the shoes of Carl "CJ" Johnson, returning from his native Los Santos to bury his mother and reconnect with his family (both biological and street). In an unsurprising twist, CJ is soon thrown into a criminal maelstrom of gang wars, corrupt cops, triads and conspiracy theories, which gradually take him to the cities of San Fierro and Las Venturas, replicating parts of California and Nevada. Following the example of the previous part, you gradually work your way up from a petty criminal to the boss of a giant mafia empire. And all this to the sound of classic nineties hip hop. The American dream of every boy growing up in the ghetto.

Compared to the previous installments, San Andreas could be summed up in one word - more massive. The game world is much bigger and brings an incredible amount of new activities that can keep you busy for tens of hours. In addition to the obligatory four tasks in a taxi, ambulance, police or fire truck, this time you will also enjoy apartment burglaries, aerial acrobatics, swimming, dating or "dancing" lowriders. At the time, the game offered as a big draw the possibility of modifying the main character's appearance - in addition to the traditional changes of suits and hairstyles, you were given the opportunity to improve your hero's abilities and influence his physique by visiting a gym or a KFC. These changes then opened up new missions and the other characters reacted accordingly to CJ. From a game point of view, it was a perfectly polished diamond that Rockstar carefully worked on for three years, and the game deservedly collected absolute ratings.

Gamers' hunger for nostalgia was so strong that Rockstar decided to call this gem back from retirement and offer it with the Unreal Engine polish. Rockstar would add another box office hit under its belt and revive the excitement surrounding the continuation of the series. However, this job should not be given to the studio Grove Street Games.. instead of quick bucks, Rockstar has rather embarrassed himself.
Just as CJ's unsurprising twist at the beginning of his story awaited players, this unsurprisingly messed-up remaster awaits players. [b] 75% [/b]

As most people I've heard in advance how horrible the definitive edition is for all 3 games and not to bother playing it. After waiting a few months for patches to be applied I decided to give it a shot as it was on sale.

Out of the 3 remasters GTA SA is the least improved one of the bunch. 

[b]Stability/Bugs[/b]
Game is stable. I was able to finish 100% of it including all achievments. No crashes encountered.
That being said - lots of bugs, few of which actually prevent normal completion of some missions.
Example are girlfriend dates - if you take them on a food date afterwards game soft locks. They stick with you and date wont end unless you kill them. You need to use a different bug to force complete a date by going into a gym. 
Some missions have missing audio dialogue. You see subtitles but no sound, or other way around.
Audio in radio stations have a tendency to cut-off and suddenly start playing next song. 
Some missions have desynced cutscenes, where audio is late.
Oh and of course floating cars, cars driving in air, cars spawning in each other causing explosions, cars spawning and driving in reverse (original bug from 2004) and lots of random issues similar to this all around the game.
In some cutscenes character models break and  eg CJ can move his torse while his legs are stuck in one place making his model tear apart.

Overall, game is stable, but does require some workarounds for some missions to be able to finish it fully.

[b]Visuals[/b]
Even with latest patch and few mods installed there are a lot of noticable visual bugs.
Distant LODs look horrible. Ability to see entire map from higher altitude breaks the immersion of its size.
A lot of roads in countrysides are not connected to the grass areas, leaving holes into the void, which you can clip thru and fall down. Very noticable as you drive around.  The sesert tunnel is missing entire model for entrance. You can see entire mountain inside, huge hole.
Some objects float in the middle of the street, eg. street lamps in the middle of a road in LV floating mid air which you can actually hit. Some random "tires" on country roads that from a distance look like a clipping car or tree.  Often cars spawn clipping into the road. Road collisions in some areas different than the road model, which makes your car clip into the ground, sometimes fully (on main roads used for story missions!).
Grass floating midair in countryside etc. So many visual issues there is no space to list them all. And worst - they are actually very noticable while playing, even if you dont look for them.

Oh and the new lightning engine actually makes some story mission areas much darker than original making it harder to navigate thru.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
As the most 'modern' of all 3 remasters, GTA SA doesnt really feel like a remaster compared to other 2. 
Not many new additions, if at all. Free cam movement, free aim etc were all already in the original GTA SA.
Visuals and new lightning engine doesnt make that much of a difference with the remaster compared to eg. GTA VC. Getting any shader for 2004 game gives better results without all those new bugs.  
Maybe some textures are sharper, car reflections look better, but thats not that noticable here.

Due to all listed bugs and visual glitches above the gameplay is actually much worse than in the original. 
Basically nothing new added  but a lot of things taken away due to bugs. 

Did  I also mention that majority of weather conditions are gone? Fog in San Fierro? Forget about it. Sand Storms in LV? More like a poorly added filter/texture on all objects which breaks any immersion left.
All 3 cities/areas look and feel the same, so orange sunsets in LS, no heat waves in LV. Same weather everywhere....
Oh and objects you can break have no ragdol and just "drown" into the land in an unnatural way.

[b]Summary[/b]
Not worth it. Play original with even shitties shaders and you will get much better experience.
Only positive thing this remaster adds are sharper textures, car models and reflections, but all those things can be modded in original with better results. 
And it introduces a TON of bugs/soft locks/visual gliches and many immersion breaking moments.

Yes, its playable. Yes you can finish it 100% (with usage of glitches and bugs to combat other bugs) and Yes, it looks visually better (kinda) than the original, but its NOT worth it at all.

Play original if you want to replay this game.

Firstly the positives. The updated visuals are a very noticeable improvement from the original, and the modern facelift gives the game crisper textures, enhanced lighting. The core gameplay experience is more or less the same as it was in the classic with the open-world exploring, driving and shooting which i am glad remains intact from the classic.

However despite these positives, the game still falls short in a few ways which might leave some people disappointed. One glaring issue was a few technical bugs. Usually its just visual glitches like characters/vehicles suddenly disappearing, to more severe issues like crashing. These frustrating issues should have been ironed out by now, which is quite disappointing as you would expect something more from Rockstar.

In conclusion; The definitive edition is a mixed review from me, the improved visuals and preserving the original games detail remain a positive for me, but the numerous issues, horrible character models and missing content soured my overall experience. So, before I start this review, I wanna make one thing clear:

GTA San Andreas is a great game

GTA San Andreas - The Definitive Edition is not.

I wanted to make that clear because I love San Andreas. I first played it on the Original Xbox, and I loved it. I then found out it was on the Xbox 360, and I didn't like it as much as the OG Xbox version. The only thing the Xbox 360 and PS3 versions have going for them are the Achievements/Trophies (and the PS2 classics version that was on the PS4/PS5 store). I then bought the original game on Steam because I was getting more into PC by then and decided "why not? It's a great game," and I loved it. A few years later, my dad gave me a bunch of his old games, and the PS2 version was among them, so I played it and loved it more than the OG Xbox version because the PS2 is my favorite console.

So then in 2021, Rockstar decided to remaster GTA 3, Vice City and San Andreas. I'm sorry, did I type "remaster?" What I meant to type was they took the Mobile versions, ported them to Consoles and PC, called them remasters, and removed the originals from digital storefronts. Oh and they had Grove Street Games, formally known as War Drum Studios, do it, and they haven't been known to make good ports. Now I'm pretty sure Rockstar did give people the originals on the Rockstar Games launcher for free after the backlash, but I don't know about steam since I already had the originals before.

This version pretty much sucks and I'm only into it for the Achievements. I was in an Ambulance doing the Paramedic mission, and when I got to level 10 after like 20 minutes, one of the patients was underground down some stairs. I couldn't find her for a long time, but I finally did in the nick of time and had to drive the Ambulance into the small tunnel. I have also run into this issue where Grass is just floating in mid air.

Their are many other reasons as to why the "Definitive" Edition sucks.

If you want this game, here are a few recommendations:
1. If you have a Xbox One or Xbox Series X/S, get a physical copy of San Andreas on the Xbox 360 or OG Xbox since they are Backwards Compatible. The OG Xbox disc downloads the 360 version, but since the OG Xbox version is usually cheaper, I would get that one.
2. If you have a PS2 or OG Xbox, get it on there.
3. If you have a PS3 or Xbox 360, get it on there. They are also mobile ports, but I would say they are still better than the "Definitive" Edition. I'm not sure if putting a PS2/OG Xbox copy of the game in a PS3/Xbox 360 plays the PS2/OG Xbox version or the PS3/Xbox 360 version, someone else will have to verify that. If the PS3 and Xbox 360 do play the PS2/OG Xbox version when you do that, then I would buy the PS2/OG Xbox version.
4. I'm not sure if this would work, but if you only have a PC, then you could try finding a physical copy of the original game.
5. Not that you should do this, but if you only have a PC and don't feel like spending extra money, you could download a PS2 emulator and the GTA San Andreas PS2 ISO file and play it like that. If you do go the emulator route, I would only recommend the PS2 version.

Thats my review.

GTA: San Andreas = Yay

GTA: San Andreas - The Definitive Edition = Nay

Short summary:
Buy this game if you also have a nostalgic attachment to them. I brought it at half price. However if you are experiencing this game for the first time, proceed with purchasing but just know that these games haven't been shown love or attention needed to make them enjoyable. I still prefer the welcomed upgrades in this edition over the original games so I will continue to play this version.

Some of these reviews on GTA San Andreas are extreme left or right. They either have a troll comment with a positive recommendation given or they are hating on the game without balance or explanation. Which is IRONIC because they have given bad reviews but their playtime is extremely lengthy. I'm here to provide a balanced review with some details of what you will enjoy and what issues you will face.

Full Review:
I have been playing San Andreas for the last few weeks and I have noticed so many bugs from the beginning of my play-through. These bugs are not game breaking (meaning you can progress through the story) but rather a disappointment to this majestic title. Let me explain.

The game looks visually pleasing and the upgraded textures are a welcome. The new weapon wheel, radio wheel, world lighting, controller support, mission restart and fake building interiors are much welcomed to allow this game to feel modernised. Which is why I would always prefer this game over the original but it is a real shame that Rockstar  put such little effort to bring these 3 titles to a polished standard even after Grove Street Games (a mobile game developer) had failed to release these games in a playable state. GSG is not at fault because they are a small team who did their best to execute and meet the given deadlines to launch these games. Rockstar decided to give these classic, nostalgic and generation defining games to a team who is incapable of being able to serve these games the attention and level of skill required to bring them to modern standard. It really frustrates fans who love these games and want to experience their glory once again 20 years later.

In this section of my review I will go through some of the issues that still exist in this game. Before I start, these are my PC Specs:

CPU Ryzen 7 7700x
GPU RX 6950 XT
I am playing the game on MAX settings
I play on a 34" Ultra Wide monitor (21:9 aspect ratio)

Issues:

*edit:*
There are 3 game impacting things which no body has really mentioned online or in reviews:

- You cannot shoot/snipe someone out of their vehicle. There's an invisible glass that wont break. You also cant shoot someone off their bike. If they are in a vehicle it is almost as if they are safe from all bullets. Some missions need you to shoot people off bikes and now you need to blow up the whole vehicle to kill them.

- I play and switch between Keyboard & Mouse and Controller. When I use KBM, I notice that it is EXTREMELY difficult to look upwards and downwards EVEN if i increase my DPI and in-game sensitivity settings. This issue and the issue above were not present in the original game which makes it even more frustrating.

- The last thing is related to LOD which is an extension of my point below. Whilst driving, if you spin your camera around to look back and then spin it back to look ahead, cars near by will stay but cars at a moderately close distance will disappear. If you press the scroll wheel (or R3 on controller) to look back no cars disappear. The fact that this even happens is disappointing.

*end edit*

-LOD (level of detail) especially at a distance is awful. Buildings look like a mount of clay. Then as you get closer it will load in correctly in higher LOD.

-Perfomance stutters every once in a while. I play on 165hz and it is smooth for the most part but a few stutters happen randomly.

-21:9 ultrawide screen is supported but sometimes the HUD (heads up display) is adjusted perfectly and other times it is stretched or miss placed. The cutscenes will have black bars (reasonable) but sometimes the cutscene is more to the right making the left black bar thick and right black bar thin.

-Fences + thick bushes which split the road in two, do not cause collision upon contact. You will walk/drive right through them.

- The fog isn't significant to allow similar feeling to original title. It barely exists and you can see the whole 3 cities from the Maze Tower. Disappointing because the fog added a level of mystery to the far distance and made the map feel bigger. Now it feels weird seeing how small the map is when in reality it isn't that small.

-On a lot of roads especially motorways, there are weird pop up textures from below the ground. They look like palm leaves in shape and car tires in texture.

-When destroying lamp posts or traffic light poles, they will fall straight through the ground.

-Lighting in cutscenes sometimes can be too dark so some characters cant be seen. Most cutscenes look exceptional however.

- Limited amount of cars on motorways and sometimes not a lot of NPC's in areas where the original game had plenty.

-CJ's hand misplacement-  for example when using the gym tools, riding a motorbike or when drinking soda.

-Certain character facial expressions and textures look poorly designed.

-When you are driving and passing buidlings, details continously pop up even though I am playing on Max settings. This is extremely frustrating especially for vegetation that pops up because there are so many more loading in real time rather than at a distance.

-The radio wheel and weapon wheel lack colour, distinction and personality

-The aiming/aim assist system is so bad. They should've used the aim assist from gta 5 which can allow you to free aim if you want. Rather than having it as either always a free aim OR always strong aim assist.

-Some fan favourite & nostalgic radio tracks have been removed.

-THE MOST IMPORTANT TO ME IS NO CO-OP HOT SPOTS :(

If i remember more I will add them but these are my main complains. I have been on a roller coaster of hope, disappointment and then back to the realisation that these games will most likely never be touched again.

Sad when you realise that Rockstar could have done so much more to the games that have filled so many childhood memories. These 3 games literally set the industry standard for open world and they still hold up even after 20 years.

Rockstar to cut off the hand that fed them is truly a shame.

I hope my review has been helpful. 

Thank you for your time.

The buggiest mess of the so-called Definitive Trilogy, SADE is atrociously ugly in every regard. The game basically works and runs ok at 60FPS, but this looks absolutely disgusting. 

The character models are by far some of the worst of this generation. Where the game had perfectly fine low-quality LOD meshes for distant buildings, SADE introduces absolutely horrible decimated meshes that look like the stuff of dreadful fever dreams with triangles jutting out in all directions, done through automation. The world has no fog or cloud haze or depth, so when you're flying a plane, you can see that the map is 10km wide and can see to very ends of the San Andreas state (!) up to the edge of the sea, visibly a mere water volume, where the game fades into a volume trigger (which respawns you back into water if you swim to it) beyond which there is nothing. Where the game previously had acceptably good (not just for the time!) cloud cover, this game has none on low detail modes for low power devices like Steam Deck. There is no excuse for not supporting a basic level of fidelity in a remaster at low option modes.

There are no major bugs, no show-stoppers, and everything is in line with the revision done for the mobile port, but there are numerous physics bugs now and ped despawning for some reason still happens 17 years after release. It's again badly optimized, with streaming of geometry and assets at 60FPS presenting consistent and repeatable stuttering on low-power devices such as Steam Deck. However the game basically looks uglier than any other version and still does not match PS2-grade post effects. 

Since GTASA is no longer available in its original form, I'm again disinclined to hit this with a flat No, because there will likely never again be a re-release of GTASA in its OG engine (remember Star Wars Special Edition?) and so this is the way people growing up in 2023 and born after 2023 will experience the game. It's a sub-par remaster, but it's still one of the best games ever made in history, so I have to give this a reluctant Yes with the addition that it's the ugliest game I think I've ever played.

Even though I know better, I still had to buy the Definitive Edition Trilogy, purely because these three games made my childhood. We would go over to my friends house literally every day after school with my PS2 copy of San Andreas and all the cheat codes written down on a piece of paper inside my backpack.

And it is for this reason, that these three Remakes are so disappointing. The original 3D-Trilogy of the Grand Theft Auto series did not only make my, but other childhoods as well. Not only that, but it also put Rockstar Games on the map for decades to come. You would certainly think that they would put some love into these three games especially, but they instead decided to hand the work to an under-staffed studio, which does not seem to have a single bit of love or care for the original titles. These games should have gotten the Rockstar treatment we have gotten used to: In-house development and a care for the tiniest of details.

Now, are these Remakes really that bad? No, not at all. All three titles look amazing with the new skyboxes, volumetric clouds, dynamic lights, upgraded models and AI-enhanced textures. But this is the bare minimum that they could have put into these games anyways, because underneath the new Unreal-Renderer there are still the old codebases running. This could have very well been a free update to the existing, older titles, as a gesture of good-will for the upcoming Grand Theft Auto VI or a tie-in event in GTA: Online. Yet, they decided to sell the Trilogy at full price, while they didn't even put a meaningful amount of resources into this project.

While I do realize that Grove Street Games (WarDrum Studios) is at fault here, it is not fair to give Rockstar Games a pass on this, like most GTA fans seem to do. They had to have at least taken a look onto these games and given the final green light to make this release happen. This makes them just as guilty for how bad these ports are.

And to withhold other remakes and updates for the PC version of RDR2, just because the reception to the Definitive Edition Trilogy wasn't as good as they had expected (deservingly) seems really petty and embarassing on Rockstar's part. And it is for all of these reasons, that I cannot recommend this game, while I do enjoy the new visuals, which will make the Trilogy viable for another decade.

This is the worst game launch and remaster I've ever seen. You may think that's hyperbole with all of the garbage releases in recent years (Halo: MCC, Assassin's Creed: Unity, Cyberpunk 2077, etc.), but I'm totally sincere. Here's a long list of everything I can think of that this game does poorly, as well as the mistakes made by Rockstar and co. themselves.

-Playstation players got unintended early access, meanwhile PC players had to wait days to play it after a few hours after launch with no explanation of why or when it would come back until the day before it finally did. Why? They left assets in the game code they didn't want public. Not just a few things, but a ton. If that doesn't speak to how amateur this project is, I don't know what does.
-The game released in an inexcusably abysmal state:
-This game is chock full of bugs. 
-The atmospheres of these games are ruined. Instead of GTA III's distinctly moody vibe, served by its blue tone and unusual soundscape, you have an ugly, grey, bland and overly dark visual backed by extremely muffled audio that sounds significantly worse than the original PC release. Instead of SA's sunny, orange hue, you have a generic artstyle. VC suffers from many of the problems found in the other two games, but it always had a vivid, larger than life aesthetic, and so the cartoony models and exaggerated colours don't look totally out of place.
-As a general statement about the artstyles of these games, they look too cartoony. This now seems to be purposeful, unlike the original games which only looked cartoony as a result of their limited technology and not due to an intended style. Now that we have better tech, there's no reason outside of budget and developmental constraints that they shouldn't look as realistic as they were originally intended to be. Colours are too vivid and the lighting gives everything a plastic, glossy look (characters look like action figures).
-Ambient occlusion is too strong, making the games look ridiculously dark at times - especially in cutscenes. Turning it off however makes the game look flat and outdated.
-Misaligned and ill fitting textures everywhere.
-Performance is dreadful. Why does a game from 2001, which looks worse in many areas than its original release, run significantly worse than brand new games built from the ground up released in 2023?
-"Improved combat" is a lie. The auto aim isn't even as snappy as the controller input (GInput) mod for the original versions of the games. The only thing they did to improve it was allow you to move while firing some weapons and add a weapon wheel. Wow. Incredible.
-Missing music from the original games - a lot of it. Hardly "definitive", is it? You're a multi-billion dollar company. You make more in a year from GTA: Online than most game developers and publishers ever see. I'm certain you could've afforded to re-license some songs, cheapskates... just as I'm sure you could've afforded to hire more than some mobile developers to remaster the games that got you where you are today.
-Censorship: GTA III, and to a lesser extent, GTA VC's heavy dismemberment, made killing so satisfying. Now there are just occasional decapitations. Why?
-Rockstar exclusive for a year with no announcement that it would come to any other platform until it randomly appeared a week or so ago on Steam. Why? They didn't want people waiting to purchase it on Steam. They wanted us to buy it on the Rockstar Game Launcher. Exclusives suck as is, but most publishers at least tell players ahead of time they they're limited exclusives. Rockstar didn't want to do this.
-Misspellings everywhere due to AI upscaling. These should've been impossible to miss.
-Again the audio is horrendous. Why does everything sound so muffled?
-III and particularly VC have the worst AI I've ever seen in video games, regardless of era. Unbelievably, they're even WORSE now.
-Broken collision and geometry. Fall through maps, hit invisible fences, etc.
-The occasional clunkiness of the original games' movement hasn't been resolved.
-Minor but still noticeable and offensive changes to gameplay - both done on purpose and things overlooked.
-AI upscaled textures are the bane of modern modding and game development, from a consumer's point of view. I have no idea why anyone thinks these look good. I've yet to see a single example of upscaled textures, outside of ultra low resolution pixel art that looks like anything other than a grainy, fake mess. This game's full of them.
-The radar now has a GPS for mission objectives that you can't turn off. This is a nice addition as an option, but the maps are small enough so as to not warrant it for me personally, and so I'd rather be able to use the minimap to plan my route myself on the fly without being guided the whole way through. It's a difficult thing to ignore. Honestly, this is one of my biggest gripes with this release even though I appreciate what they were trying to do. Is it really that hard to just add an option to disable it, though? GTA IV and V have this option.
-A full year later and almost nothing has changed. It's been a year since we've had a sizeable update.
-No separate sensitivity settings for vehicles and on-foot.
-Rockstar and Grove Street Games were dismissive in attitude towards their massive failure, adding further insult to injury. The fake apologies were late, too.
-You can't buy the games separately... despite launching and downloading them separately. Why? Because Rockstar knows nostalgia is a powerful tool and that people will pay the full price of admission for even one of these games. People can rightfully bag 343i all they want, but when they re-released the Halo games on Steam, they didn't force you to buy all of them at once. They allowed you to buy each of the six games contained by themselves, paying only $11AUD for each. THAT's good customer service and business practise. What Rockstar have done here is spit in your face.
-Even for 3 remastered games, regardless of how well they released, $90AUD is a lot to charge.
-Camera modes are weird. They're either too close or too far. No in between. I don't have this problem with the originals or other Rockstar games.
-Auto view centering is really annoying. Please let us turn it off.
-Even the desktop/Steam icons look ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ dreadful.
-The price is much higher in some regions because Rockstar are idiots.
-Some achievements are mission specific, and given that you can't replay individual missions, if you miss it the first time then you have to restart the entire game just to get to the point where you can earn the achievement again. Some of these are "secret" achievements, too. The developers realise these are incredibly long games, right?
-The difficulty of these games have been decreased in specific missions for the sake of bad players.

As you may or may not be aware, this game is full of bugs that the original did not have. The original did have a few bugs, but for the most part they were very few in-between and harder to encounter than the ones found in this "Definitive Edition".
You cannot have custom music like in the original game by dropping music to a folder (the custom radio has been removed, from a 2004 game that HAD it...)
The camera is non-functional. (With the old camera, whenever you took pictures, those would save as in-game screenshots in a folder in your PC). You can take pictures with it, but no picture will be saved to your PC.
Still, having Steam achievements is nice I guess...
Is it fun? Yeah, can be.
Is it better than the original? Definitely NO. This is supposed to be a "Definitive Edition", but it has greatly failed, at the bare minimum, a Definitive Edition should have as few bugs as possible, and even though more bugs have been fixed than when the game came out, it's still full of them. Not only that, but it has had features replaced entirely or, much worse yet, completely removed or not working correctly.
Sometimes your feet will sink in some surfaces, pedestrians sometimes sit on the wrong part of a seat. (Easiest to see in benches by the beach in Los Santos)
In short; You can play this version of GTA San Andreas if you want, but the only worthy thing about it is that you get achievements on Steam and that it looks kinda prettier in most cases. If I were you I'd hesitate to buy this product unless its price is really lowered, I bought the Trilogy on a 50% sale and the value of the product is not really reflected well with the level of care, which is probably why when GTA VI comes out, I'll be extra hesitant to pick it up. (As I was with this product at first, I only ended up adquiring it since they did fix some of the bugs and put it on Steam, as well as put it on sale.)
It is also disappointing that despite all the resources they have nowadays as a company, they couldn't bother to for instance, bring PS2 co-op mode or something of the sorts.
Was it so hard, Rockstar? Because I do not think so.
I even got stuck at the pool game inside of the bar near Grove Street. (It all got stuck, extremely glitchy!)
Same can be said about the basketball mini-game too.
All in all, it's a fun experience, but for the price they're asking? Not worth it AT ALL. Enough said. Pick it up at your own discretion, and ONLY during a sale.

I bought this to see if all the negative press was correct, and I can safely say that it was. Note that I have not played the original trilogy. Here is my list of things I noticed:

The visuals are very bizarre, and just look very strange. The textures were clearly upscaled without actually looking at them, and the models can be very strange as well. This may just be my opinion, but the game just looks so strange. I somewhat got used to it, but never fully.

Many cutscenes seemed to have issues, with characters walking into walls. Lampposts and streetlights would fall into the ground when you hit them with a car, which could be in the original game as well, but it's still strange.

The performance was not good. This was clearly not optimized very well. (I would like to note that I played on linux, so maybe some of these are not the games fault, but I doubt that from what others are saying.) Sometimes after finishing a mission or just going into the menu, the game would drop to about 20 fps and stay around there for a while before suddenly returning to 60. There were also some stutters as well.

The worst part about this is that we can no longer buy the original trilogy on steam, so we are stuck with the defective editions. I would not recommend this, even for 50% off and certainly not $60. If you really want to buy this, wait for a very very deep discount (like $10) I was hopeful that the game would get a patch when it came to Steam, but I guess not. Do. Not. Buy.

I'm going to go out on a limb here and say this game is pretty good.

I own the original edition on Steam, so when this was first released, I redownloaded it and played it. After all, mods can do everything this game did and more right? Well, I found modding this game to be a bit troublesome. I would have numerous issues, either with the gamepad mods to work with certain missions, such as the lowrider mission or even just using hydraulics in general. Other times, I would start missions and my game would instantly crash, like the missions OG Loc gives you after the bike chase. I would scour gtaforums and Reddit and other things to find fixes to these issues but would often spend more time troubleshooting issues than actually enjoying the game. Or, with an unlocked frame rate, I would be unable to use the treadmill unless I went and edited the FPS back to 30. I just had a bunch of weird issues like that. Ultimately, that's just a thing that happens when you try to play older games on newer OS's and hardware. In some cases they are kind of tricky to get working just right.

I don't have any of those issues in this game. 

There are also so many other good QOL changes they made in this game. For instance, in the original, scrolling through menus at Burger Shot was annoying because you had to press the button to see each next food item individually. Now there is a list. You can instantly replay missions after failing them, unlike before where you had to drive all the way back to mission start each and every time. The controller support is good, there's a weapon wheel, unlocked framerate that has none of the issues I mentioned above and more.

Is it a perfect remake? No way. The new textures look...weird. On max settings, some things look surprisingly good, but on weird blocky textures and it just doesn't look right. The original game with graphics mods does feel better, in my opinion. Also the way in which Rockstar rolled this game out originally is really bad, and there was no quality control at all. It's also a shame they didn't release this on Steam with a new patch that would fix issues other people are having. You also can't rebind buttons on the controller (shame).

But overall, I think comparing the two experiences, I have had a better time with this version of the game then trying to deal with the modded version, with all it's issues framerate issues and crashing. I'm actually playing it and having fun this time rather than messing with .ini files, hoping to find an answer for an issue on the internet, or playing for several hours only to have a mission crash the game any time you are trying to start it.

Would recommend (on sale of course).
